case_name: Appellants v. Collector of Customs, Calcutta

facts.text: Appellants imported a large quantity of electrical instruments (fluorescent tubes and fluorescent fixtures) from USA into India under a licence.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants had brought into India from the S.A. a large quantity of electrical instruments under a licence. The respondent, the Collector of Customs, Calcutta, started proceedings for companyfiscation of these goods tinder s.167 8  of the Sea Customs Act, 1878.

facts.text: Licence granted to first appellant (company) on October 8, 1948 to import fluorescent tubes and fixtures from USA.

anchor.surface_text: On October 8, 1948, a licence was granted to the appellant to import from the U.S.A. a large quantity of electrical instruments, namely fluorescent tubes and fluorescent fixtures.

facts.text: Licence condition: goods to be utilised only for consumption as raw material or accessories in licence holders factory, no portion sold to any party.

anchor.surface_text: The licence was issued subject to the companydition that the goods would be utilised only for companysumption as raw material or accessories in the licence holders factory and that numberportion thereof would be sold to any party.

facts.text: Goods cleared out of customs about end of February 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The goods duly arrived in India and were cleared out of the customs sometime about the end of February, 1949.

facts.text: Authorities received information that goods were being sold in market in breach of licence condition.

anchor.surface_text: Soon thereafter, the authorities companycerned are said to have got information that the goods were being sold in the market in breach of the companydition of the licence.

facts.text: Police seized large stock of goods from appellants' godown on August 12, 1949 pursuant to search warrant.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the police took steps and after obtaining a search warrant from a Magistrate in Calcutta on August 12, 1949, seized a large stock of the goods from the godown of the appellants.

facts.text: Prosecution of appellants' officers including second appellant under IPC s.420 r/w s.120B started January 12, 1951; discharged July 27, 1953 by Presidency Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter on January 12, 1951, two proceed. ings were started. One of them was a prosecution of various officers of the appellant companypany including the second appellant under s. 420 read with s. 120 of the Indian Penal Code...

facts.text: Prosecution under s.5 Import & Exports Control Act 1947 against second appellant; acquittal by trial court confirmed by Calcutta High Court on March 3, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The other proceeding was a prosecution of the second appellant and another person under s.5 of the Act of 1947. ... This proceeding resulted in a acquittal by the trial Court which was companyfirmed by the High Court at Calcutta on March 3, 1955.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court ordered seized goods sold on January 16, 1953; sale proceeds Rs. 4,15,000 kept with Chief Presidency Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: While these proceedings were pending an order was made by the High Court on January 16, 1953, directing the seized goods to be sold and the sale proceeds kept with the Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta.

facts.text: Collector of Customs served show cause notice on appellants on August 28, 1955 for confiscation of sale proceeds under Sea Customs Act s.167(8) r/w Import Act s.3(2).

anchor.surface_text: After the aforesaid proceedings had companye to an end, the Collector of Customs, Calcutta on August 28, 1955, served a numberice on the appellant to show cause why the moneys lying with the Chief presidency Magistrate...

facts.text: Appellants filed petition under Art.226 Constitution in Calcutta High Court for writ of prohibition against Collector; dismissed by Sinha J., appeal dismissed January 5, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: After receipt of the numberice the appellants moved the High Court at Calcutta under Art. 226 of the Constitution for a writ of prohibition prohibiting the respondent, the Collector of Customs, Calcutta, from taking any proceeding...

facts.text: Supreme Court Civil Appeal No. 383 of 1960 by special leave from Calcutta High Court judgment dated January 5, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 383 of 1960, Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 5, 1959, of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Order No. 54 of 1957.

facts.text: Application for licence filed September 27, 1948 stating goods for own use in factory at Ellore, Madras.

anchor.surface_text: On September 27, 1948, the appellant-Company filed an application with the Chief Controller of Imports, New Delhi for the grant of a licence to import 20, 000 fluorescent tubes and 2,000 fluorescent fixtures from the United States of America.

facts.text: Goods imported between March 21-26, 1949, value within licence ceiling, larger quantity than applied but value ok.

anchor.surface_text: Between March 21, 1949, and March 26, 1949, the appellants took delivery of the said tubes and fixtures of the specified value and cleared them on payment of customs duty.

facts.text: Police seized goods August 31, 1949 from godown (note slight date diff in judgments).

anchor.surface_text: On August 31, 1949, the said Police establishment obtained a search warrant from the Chief presidency Magistrate, Calcutta, and seized, among others, from the appellants godown a large stock of fluorescent tubes and fixtures...

facts.text: Goods sold for Rs. 4,15,000 pursuant to High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this order the goods were sold for a sum of Rs. 4,15,000 and the sale proceeds have since been lying with the Chief Presidency Magistrate.

facts.text: Show cause notice alleged goods sold to others in breach of condition and licence obtained by fraudulent misrepresentation.

anchor.surface_text: The numberice stated that ... investigation had revealed that portion of the goods were sold by the appellants to other people.

facts.text: Notification No. 23-I.T.C./43 deemed issued under Import Act, prohibiting import of electrical instruments without licence.

anchor.surface_text: By Notification No. 23-I.T.C./43 issued under r. 84 of the Defence of India Rules which by virtue of s. 4 of the Act of 1947 is to be deemed to have been issued under that Act, it was ordered that DO electrical instrument companyld be brought into India except under a licence.

facts.text: Notification No. 2-ITC/48 dated March 6, 1948 allowed licences subject to condition no disposal without permission.

anchor.surface_text: By another order made under s. 3 of the Act and companytained in Notification No. 2- ITC/48, dated March 6, 1948, it was provided that the licence to import electrical instruments might be issued subject to the companydition that the goods would number be disposed of or otherwise dealt with without the written permission of the licensing authority.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal allowed by majority (Subba Rao J.), writ of prohibition issued against Collector.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the order of the High Court is set aside and the appeal is allowed with companyts. There will be an order of prohibition restraining the Customs Authority from proceeding with the inquiry under s.167 8  of the Sea Customs Act.

facts.text: First appellant is East India Commercial Co. Ltd., registered office Calcutta; second appellant is its director.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are Messrs. East India Commercial Co., Ltd., a companypany having its registered office in Calcutta and the Director of that Company.

facts.text: Goods value approx CIF Rs. 3,33,333; seized stock value about Rs. 4,66,000 including duty.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned at this stage that the value of the stock imported was about Rs. 4,66,000 i.e., the purchase price of Rs. 3,33,333, together with the customs duty paid on the said goods.

issues.text: has the Collector jurisdiction to adjudicate whether the goods are liable to be confiscated?

anchor.surface_text: The appellants, therefore, ask for a writ of prohibition directing the Collector to stop the proceedings. The question is, has the Collector jurisdiction to adjudicate whether the goods are liable to be confiscated?

issues.text: whether the petition filed by the appellants under Art. 226 of the Constitution for the issue of a writ in the nature of prohibition is maintainable

anchor.surface_text: The first question is whether the petition filed by the appellants under Art. 226 of the Constitution for the issue of a writ in the nature of prohibition is maintainable in the circumstances of the case.

issues.text: what is the true construction of the provisions of the relevant sections?

anchor.surface_text: The next question is, what is the true construction of the provisions of the relevant sections? It would be convenient at this stage to read the relevant parts of ss. 3 and 5 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: 1 The Collector of Customs has jurisdiction to consider under s. 167 (8) if the Sea Customs Act whether the goods are imported contrary to the restrictions imposed under the Act

anchor.surface_text: If on a reading of the said notice, it is manifest that... no one of the conditions laid down in the specified sections was contravened, the respondent would have no jurisdiction

issues.text: whether law declared by High Court is binding on tribunals under its superintendence like Customs Collector

anchor.surface_text: This raises the question whether an administrative tribunal can ignore the law declared by the highest court in the State and initiate proceedings in direct violation of the law so declared.

issues.text: whether public notices constitute orders under s.3 of the Act imposing conditions

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the respondent argues that a public notice issued by the Government on July 26, 1948, is an order made... and that the order directs the imposition of a condition

issues.text: whether goods imported under licence obtained by misrepresentation are deemed imported without licence
whether s.167(8) applies only to acts before or during import, not post-import breach

arguments.claim: Proceedings are without jurisdiction as Collector can confiscate only for import contravening prohibition/restriction under order, not mere breach of licence condition

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, the Collector of Customs, Calcutta, started proceedings for confiscation of these goods under s.167(8) of the Sea Customs Act, 1878. The appellants contend that the proceedings are entirely without jurisdiction as the Collector can confiscate only when there is an import in contravention of an order prohibiting or restricting it and in the present case the Collector was proceeding to confiscate on the ground that a condition of the licence under which the goods had been imported had been disobeyed.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ated Schedule IV only mentioned five numberifications issued under s. 3 of the Act, but numberpublic numberice was included in that list. To put it di

arguments.court_reasoning: Breach of licence condition is not contravention of order under s.3 IECA; s.167(8) SCA only for contravention of prohibition/restriction order

arguments.claim: Collector has no jurisdiction under s.167(8) SCA r/w s.182 SCA to decide breach of licence condition as it is not breach of order u/s.3(1) IECA

anchor.surface_text: As earlier stated the question is one of jurisdiction. The contention of learned counsel for the appellant is that under s. 167(8) of the Sea Customs Act read with s. 182 of that Act under which the Collector of Customs is proceeding, he has jurisdiction only to decide whether goods have been imported contrary to the prohibition or restriction imposed by an order made under s. 3(1) of the Act of 1947 but he has no jurisdiction under these sections to decide any question of confiscation of goods for breach of a condition of a licence issued under such an order.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ated Schedule IV only mentioned five numberifications issued under s. 3 of the Act, but numberpublic numberice was included in that list. To put it di

arguments.court_reasoning: Confirmed by majority; dissent rejected

arguments.court_reasoning: Notice is speaking; discloses no order contravention; quasi-judicial requires disclosing grounds

arguments.claim: Customs authorities have concurrent jurisdiction with criminal courts; not bound by HC/criminal findings

anchor.surface_text: The Customs Authorities have a concurrent jurisdiction with the criminal Court to deal with matters entrusted to them under the Acts and, therefore, the findings of a criminal court or even of a High Court on the same or similar matters could not bind them

court_response_anchor.surface_text: r of the following circumstances cancel licences issue by any officer authorised to do so under clauses  viii  to  xiv  of the numberification of the

arguments.court_reasoning: HC precedent binding on tribunals under superintendence

arguments.claim: Licence condition imposed under s.3 IECA order; breach is contravention attracting s.167(8) SCA

anchor.surface_text: The condition imposed in a licence is under the relevant order issued by the Central Government in exercise of its power under s. 3 of the Act, and, as the appellants infringed that condition, the goods imported are liable to be confiscated under s.167(8) of the Sea Customs Act, read with s.3(2) of the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Condition not part of order; Notification 2-ITC/48 empowers but does not impose; public notices not orders

arguments.claim: Goods imported on misrepresentation deemed imported without licence, liable u/s.167(8)

anchor.surface_text: As the appellants imported goods on a misrepresentation, in law the import must be deemed to be one made without a licence and therefore the goods imported are goods either prohibited or restricted within the meaning of s. 167(8) of the Sea Customs Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Licence voidable only till cancelled; no cancellation; prior acquittals/discharges

arguments.claim: Customs Collector can confiscate goods post-customs barrier; sale proceeds represent goods
arguments.court_reasoning: No jurisdiction at all; but money substitutes goods per court order

arguments.claim: Breach of licence condition is breach of order u/s.3(1) IECA; Collector has jurisdiction to decide

anchor.surface_text: The basis of the appellants contention is the proposition that a breach of the conditions of a licence is not a breach of the order under which the licence was granted and the condition imposed and that no offence under s. 167(8) of the Sea Customs Act is committed if a condition of the licence is contravened. In my view this proposition is not well founded.

arguments.court_reasoning: Majority rejects; condition not imposed by order itself

arguments.claim: Even if breach of condition not breach of order, Collector has jurisdiction to decide that question

anchor.surface_text: He has admittedly jurisdiction to decide whether there has been a breach of an order. It follows that he has jurisdiction to decide what is a breach of an order and, therefore, whether the breach of a condition of a licence is breach of an order.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ated Schedule IV only mentioned five numberifications issued under s. 3 of the Act, but numberpublic numberice was included in that list. To put it di

arguments.court_reasoning: Jurisdiction ousted if notice shows no order breach

arguments.claim: Notice alleges import without valid licence due to fraudulent misrepresentation; jurisdiction exists

anchor.surface_text: Further I think in the present case one of the allegations in the notice is that the goods had been imported without a licence and therefore in direct violation of an order made under s. 3(1) of the Act of 1947. Clearly, the Collector has jurisdiction to decide the question raised by such an allegation.

arguments.court_reasoning: Licence not void; no cancellation

arguments.claim: HC decision not binding on Collector as affects merits not jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: It is also said that the decision of a High Court on a point of law is binding on all inferior Tribunals within its territorial jurisdiction... But it seems to me that the question does not arise, for even if the decision of the High Court was binding on the Collector, that would not affect his jurisdiction.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: r of the following circumstances cancel licences issue by any officer authorised to do so under clauses  viii  to  xiv  of the numberification of the

arguments.court_reasoning: Binding on tribunals; affects jurisdiction if declares no power

arguments.claim: Breach of licence condition legitimately imposed is breach of s.3 order itself; purposive construction for efficacy

anchor.surface_text: In my view, such a breach is a breach of the order itself. Sub-section (1) of s 3 of the Act of 1947 empowers the Government to make orders prohibiting, restricting or otherwise controlling the import of goods. Now clearly, one method of restricting or controlling the import of goods would be to regulate their use or disposition after they had been brought into India.

arguments.court_reasoning: Order does not impose condition; empowers licensing authority

arguments.claim: Notifications 23-ITC/43 and 2-ITC/48 to be read together; licence under both

anchor.surface_text: Notification No. 23- ITC 43 has to be read along with Notification No. 2-ITC/48. The latter provided that a licence to import might be issued subject to a condition like the one which we have in the present case.

arguments.court_reasoning: 2-ITC/48 empowers conditions but no specific no-sale condition in order

arguments.claim: Precedent Willingale v Norris: breach of regulation under statute is breach of statute

anchor.surface_text: I find that the view that I have taken is supported by authority. Willingale v. Norris is a case fully in point... How are the words against the provisions of the Act to be read ? The two statutes are to be construed as one. In my opinion, to break the regulations made under the authority of a statute is to break the statute itself,

arguments.claim: s.167(8) applies to post-import disposition restrictions; import contrary if breached

anchor.surface_text: It seems to me that this is taking too narrow a view of s. 167(8). Suppose the order under s. 3(1) of the Imports and Exports Control Act had itself said that goods imported shall not be sold in the market without the permission of a certain authority and the goods imported were notwithstanding this sold without such permission.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not decided

arguments.claim: Sale proceeds can be confiscated as represent goods

anchor.surface_text: It remains only to consider the argument that under the Sea Customs Act only the goods imported can be confiscated and therefore, the money now lying with the Presidency Magistrate cannot be confiscated. I think this argument is wholly untenable. The money represents the goods.

arguments.court_reasoning: Majority agrees on representation

arguments.claim: Writ petition under Art.226 maintainable for prohibition if no jurisdiction on notice face

anchor.surface_text: The first question is whether the petition filed by the appellants under Art. 226 of the Constitution for the issue of a writ in the nature of prohibition is maintainable in the circumstances of the case.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: he Chief Controller of Imports or the Government of India, as the case may be, can cancel a licence after the term of the licence has expired, for num

arguments.court_reasoning: self

arguments.claim: Notice must disclose grounds for quasi-judicial proceedings; here shows no jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: Whether a statute provides for a notice or not, it is incumbent upon the respondent to issue notice to the appellants disclosing the circumstances under which proceedings are sought to be initiated against them. Any proceedings taken without such notice would be against the principles of natural justice.

arguments.claim: HC law binding on tribunals under superintendence (Arts 215,226,227); cannot ignore

anchor.surface_text: This raises the question whether an administrative tribunal can ignore the law declared by the highest court in the State and initiate proceedings in direct violation of the law so declared. Under Art. 215... Under Art. 227...

arguments.claim: s.167(8) SCA r/w s.3(2) IECA only for contravention of s.3 order, not licence condition

anchor.surface_text: The next question is, what is the true construction of the provisions of the relevant sections?... Section 167(8) of the Sea Customs Act can be invoked only if an order issued under s. 3 of the Act was infringed during the course of the import or export.

arguments.claim: Public notices are not orders u/s.3 IECA; mere policy/information
Notification 2-ITC/48 does not impose no-sale condition; only empowers administrative conditions
Licence by fraud voidable, not void; valid till cancelled by specified authority

holdings.text: The Collector of Customs lacks jurisdiction to initiate or proceed with confiscation proceedings under s.167(8) of the Sea Customs Act, 1878 read with s.3(2) of the Imports and Exports Control Act, 1947, for breach of a licence condition as it does not constitute a contravention of an order under s.3(1) of the 1947 Act.

anchor.surface_text: The first question is whether the petition filed by the appellants under Art. 226 of the Constitution for the issue of a writ in the nature of prohibition is maintainable in the circumstances of the case. A writ of prohibition is an order directed to an inferior Tribunal...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.167(8) SCA applies only to contravention of prohibition/restriction order under s.3 IECA, not administrative licence conditions; notice alleges only condition breach.

holdings.text: A petition under Article 226 for writ of prohibition is maintainable where lack of jurisdiction is apparent on the face of the show cause notice in quasi-judicial proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The first question is whether the petition filed by the appellants under Art. 226 of the Constitution for the issue of a writ in the nature of prohibition is maintainable in the circumstances of the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proceedings quasi-judicial; notice must disclose grounds per natural justice; if no jurisdiction shown, prohibition issues without full inquiry.

holdings.text: Law declared by a High Court is binding on all authorities and tribunals under its superintendence (Articles 215, 226, 227); they cannot ignore it in initiating or deciding proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: This raises the question whether an administrative tribunal can ignore the law declared by the highest court in the State and initiate proceedings in direct violation of the law so declared.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court as court of record with superintendence power implies binding effect on subordinates to avoid confusion and ensure law conformity; Calcutta HC held s.5 IECA not covering licence breach.

holdings.text: Breach of a condition in an import licence (no sale to third parties) is not a contravention of an order under s.3 of the Imports and Exports Control Act, 1947, and does not attract s.167(8) Sea Customs Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification 23-ITC/43 prohibits import without licence; 2-ITC/48 empowers licensing authority to impose conditions administratively, does not itself impose no-sale condition as part of order.

holdings.text: Public notices issued by the Government regarding import licensing principles are not 'orders' under s.3 of the Imports and Exports Control Act, 1947, but mere policy statements for guidance.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Form, content, and practice distinguish: notifications under s.3 regulate rights statutorily; public notices inform procedure without repealing prior orders or imposing penalties.

holdings.text: A licence obtained by misrepresentation or fraud is voidable, not void ab initio; it remains valid until cancelled by the competent authority (Chief Controller or Govt. of India).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Contract principles apply; specific order dated May 1, 1948 empowers cancellation post-issue for fraud/misrepresentation, but no such cancellation occurred here.

holdings.text: Quasi-judicial proceedings require a show cause notice disclosing specific circumstances/grounds of alleged contravention, per principles of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: Whether a statute provides for a notice or not, it is incumbent upon the respondent to issue notice to the appellants disclosing the circumstances under which proceedings are sought to be initiated against them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even if statute silent, natural justice mandates speaking notice; here notice specifies acts but they do not disclose s.3 order contravention.

holdings.text: Sale proceeds of seized goods, sold pursuant to court order at parties' instance to prevent deterioration, represent the goods for purposes of confiscation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Court order binding; proceeds preserved for rightful claimant; obiter as no jurisdiction to confiscate at all.

holdings.text: The appeal is allowed; High Court order set aside; writ of prohibition issued restraining Customs Authority from proceeding under s.167(8) Sea Customs Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the order of the High Court is set aside and the appeal is allowed with costs. There will be an order of prohibition restraining the Customs Authority from proceeding with the inquiry under s.167 8  of the Sea Customs Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of lack of jurisdiction findings.

anchor.surface_text: I find that the view that I have taken is supported by authority. Willingale v. Norris 1 is a case fully in point and is a much stronger case That case dealt with a prosecution under s. 19 of the London Hackney Carriages Act, 1853, which provided that for every offence against the provisions of this Act

precedents.cited_proposition: breach of regulations made under authority of a statute constitutes breach of the statute itself
precedents.cited_holding: to break the regulations made under the authority of a statute is to break the statute itself

precedents.citation: Wicks v. Director of Public Prosecutions 1

anchor.surface_text: That case received the full approval of the House of Lords in Wicks v. Director of Public Prosecutions where Viscount Simon said, There is, of course, no doubt that when a statute like the Emergency Powers (Defence) Act, 1939, enables an authority to make regu- lations, a regulation which is validly made under the Act

precedents.case_name: Wicks v Director of Public Prosecutions
precedents.cited_proposition: a regulation validly made under an Act should be regarded as though it were itself an enactment
precedents.cited_holding: when a statute like the Emergency Powers (Defence) Act, 1939, enables an authority to make regulations, a regulation which is validly made under the Act, i.e., which is intra vires of the regulation-making authority, should be regarded as though it were itself an enactment

anchor.surface_text: Then I find that in our country too the same view has been taken. Thus in Emperor Abdul Hamid Mullick, J., observed, When a notification is issued by an executive authority in exercise of a power conferred by statute, that notification is as much a part of the law as if it had been incorporated within the body of the statute

precedents.cited_proposition: a notification issued by executive authority under power conferred by statute is part of the law
precedents.cited_holding: When a notification is issued by an executive authority in exercise of a power conferred by statute, that notification is as much a part of the law as if it had been incorporated within the body of the statute at the time of its enactment

anchor.surface_text: A writ of prohibition is an order directed to an inferior Tribunal forbidding it from continuing with a proceeding therein on the ground that the proceeding is without or in excess of jurisdiction or contrary to the laws of the land, statutory or otherwise Mackonochie v. Lord Penzance 1 and Halsburys Laws of England, 3rd Edn Vol. 11, p, 52.

precedents.cited_proposition: definition and nature of writ of prohibition
